Description: Body sherd of Chian, possibly Simple Animal Style, pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black with two added red bands; exterior reserved; inscription on exterior.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis) (noted in Gardner's plate)
Curator's comments: The numbers ‘77’ and ‘2’ are written in pencil on the exterior surface. Scholtz suggests the inscription on this sherd may be a prostitute's erotically inflected pseudonym from the term 'iunx', which was an erotic charm used by Jason to seduce Medea in Pindar's fourth 'Pythian'. Sholtz, A. 'Aphrodite Pandemos at Naukratis', Greek Roman and Byzantine Studies 43, 2002-2003, 240. See also Faraone, C. A. 'The Wheel, the Whip and other Implements of torture: Erotic Magic in Pindar Pythian 4.213-19', The Classical Journal 89, 1993, no. 1, 1. The lack of decoration on the exterior surface of the sherd may be a result of the sherd's size. The decoration on the exterior surface of Simple Animal Style vases is not usually extensive and filling ornament, with the exception of a simple rim pattern, a single elaborate rosette and simple handle zone pattern, is absent.
Bibliographic references: Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (p. 63, no. 712, pl. XXI, no. 712)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 677, no. 363, pl. 21.1.5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0987) (phase 2)
